definition: treaty port, forced on Qing China by the 19th century Great Powers
to go through/to know well/(suffix) expert/to connect/to communicate/open/to clear/classifier for letters, telegrams, phone calls etc
classifier for an activity, taken in its entirety (tirade of abuse, stint of music playing, bout of drinking etc)

sentences.english: Shanghai was one of the first five treaty ports in modern China.
sentences.chinese: 作为近代中国最早的五个通商口岸之一的上海。

sentences.english: It also examines the relationship between foreign and domestic grains at the trading port level.
sentences.chinese: 本文亦在通商口岸的层次探讨两者的关系。

sentences.english: Which treaty opened Shanghai to foreign trade?
sentences.chinese: 哪个条约将上海开放成了通商口岸？

sentences.english: It allotted them five “treaty ports” through which they could conduct commerce with the Celestial Empire.
sentences.chinese: 开放五个“通商口岸”可使英国人与天朝上国做贸易。

definition: the five treaty ports forced on Qing China by the 1842 treaty of Nanjing 南京條約|南京条约 that concluded the First Opium War, namely: Guangzhou 廣州|广州, Fuzhou 福州, Ningbo 寧波|宁波, Xiamen or Amoy 廈門|厦门 and Shanghai 上海
commercial port/trading port/treaty port (old)
Treaty of Tianjin of 1858, a sequence of unequal treaties 不平等條約|不平等条约 between Russia, USA, England, France and Qing China
Treaty of Nanjing (1842) that concluded the First Opium War between Qing China and Britain
having trading relations (of nations or regions)
to open up a port for trade/to open treaty ports
concession (territory)
commercial port/trading harbor
prohibition on entering or leaving by sea
Qing government (1644-1911)
foreign concession, an enclave occupied by a foreign power (in China in the 19th and 20th centuries)
foreign trade
the Opium Wars of 1840-1842 and 1860-1861
closed-door policy
